nBackDescription: Train your working memory by remembering what appeared N steps back in the sequence.
nBackInstructions: Watch the sequence and identify when the current stimulus matches the one that appeared N positions back.
nBackComplete: You've completed the N-Back memory challenge!
selectNLevelAndStart: Select N-level and game modes, then press Start
memoryCardDescription: Test your visual memory by matching pairs of cards.
memoryCardInstructions: Click on cards to reveal them and find matching pairs. Remember the positions to match all pairs as quickly as possible.
nBackIntroduction: N-Back is a challenging cognitive exercise that trains your working memory - a critical component of cognitive function that allows you to hold and manipulate information in your mind for short periods.
nBackRule1: A sequence of visual stimuli will appear one at a time.
nBackRule2: Your task is to identify when the current stimulus matches the one that appeared N positions earlier in the sequence.
nBackRule3: Press the 'Match' button when you detect a match, or 'No Match' when there isn't one.
nBackRule4: The value of N determines the difficulty - higher N values require you to remember stimuli further back in the sequence.
nBackControlMatch: Click the 'Match' button or press the Left Arrow key
nBackControlNonMatch: Click the 'No Match' button or press the Right Arrow key
nBackPositionMode: Remember the position of the stimulus in the grid
nBackColorMode: Remember the color of the stimulus
nBackDualModeDesc: Both position and color must be remembered (more challenging)
nBackTip1: Start with N=1 or N=2 if you're new to this type of exercise.
nBackTip2: Try to maintain a steady rhythm as you respond to help with timing.
nBackTip3: Regular practice with increasing difficulty levels will yield the best results.
nBackDifficultyEasy: Suitable for beginners. You only need to remember the immediately previous stimulus.
nBackDifficultyMedium: The standard level. You need to remember what appeared 2 steps back.
nBackDifficultyHard: Challenging level requiring significant working memory capacity.
nBackDifficultyExpert: Expert level that pushes the limits of working memory.
nBackScience1: The N-Back task was developed by Wayne Kirchner in 1958 and has since become a standard measure of working memory in cognitive psychology.
nBackScience2: Working memory is a cognitive system that temporarily holds information available for processing. It's crucial for reasoning, comprehension, learning, and many everyday tasks.
nBackScience3: Research suggests that regular training with the N-Back task may improve working memory capacity, fluid intelligence, and attention control.
nBackResearch1: Improving fluid intelligence with training on working memory. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 105(19), 6829-6833.
nBackResearch2: Improving fluid intelligence with training on working memory: a meta-analysis. Psychonomic Bulletin & Review, 22(2), 366-377.
nBackResearch3: N-back training and transfer effects revealed by behavioral responses and EEG. Brain and Behavior, 8(11), e01136.
nBackBenefit1: Improves working memory capacity and performance
nBackBenefit3: May boost fluid intelligence and problem-solving abilities
nBackBenefit5: Helps with multitasking and information processing
